hedline.hl1: Shares Fall as Investors Worry About Earnings Reports

abstract.p: Nasdaq composite index falls 62.54 points, or 1.6 percent, to 3,741.22; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 9.69 points, or 0.7 percent, to 1,439.03; Dow Jones industrial average slips 39.22 points, or 0.4 percent, to 10,808.15; graph; charts (M)

block.p: Stock prices slipped again yesterday, pulled down by continued worries about coming earnings reports from big technology companies.

It appeared during morning trading that the impact of Intel's warning late Thursday about a shortfall in its third-quarter revenue figures had entirely dissipated. The Nasdaq composite index opened higher and remained in positive territory for a good part of the session.
Stock prices slipped again yesterday, pulled down by continued worries about coming earnings reports from big technology companies.

It appeared during morning trading that the impact of Intel's warning late Thursday about a shortfall in its third-quarter revenue figures had entirely dissipated. The Nasdaq composite index opened higher and remained in positive territory for a good part of the session.
But sellers began to lighten or eliminate positions in big-cap technology names later on, reasoning that if Intel was having problems, other companies must be having trouble, too.

''The fact that Intel spoke to a secular issue, meaning demand, and not a cyclical one, meaning currency, suggests that if they are having a demand slowdown so are a bunch of the rest of the gang,'' said Arthur Hogan, chief market analyst at Jefferies & Company in Boston.

Pulled down by a further decline in Intel plus drops in bellwether issues like Microsoft and Cisco Systems, the Nasdaq composite index fell for a third consecutive session, dropping 62.54 points, or 1.6 percent, to 3,741.22.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 9.69 points, or 0.7 percent, to 1,439.03. And the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 39.22 points, or 0.4 percent, to 10,808.15.

Five stocks fell for every four that rose in price on the New York Stock Exchange. Volume on the Big Board was 990 million shares. Just under 2 billion shares changed hands on the Nasdaq stock market.
Weakness in big technology stocks masked a good performance in other sectors of the market.

Financial service stocks did better, helped by a decline in market interest rates and a further drop in spot oil prices. Shares of biotechnology companies had a good day. And most big pharmaceutical stocks were good performers.
But large-cap technology names got most of the attention.
Intel, which plunged 22 percent on Friday after it issued its revenue warning, fell again yesterday. The stock closed at $45.38, down $2.56.
Cisco was another big loser, dropping $3.13, to $57.19. Hewlett-Packard dropped $6.25, to $98. And I.B.M. closed at $121.75, down $2.25.
Among Nasdaq stocks, Network Appliance was a big loser. It closed at $130.44, down $16.94, after an analyst from Wit Soundview said the company was likely to see revenue growth slow.

Ciena, by contrast, was a big winner on the Nasdaq. The fiber optic equipment maker jumped $6.81, to $127.56, after it said Korea Telecom had agreed to use Ciena systems for Internet and data-network traffic in Seoul and other cities in the country.
Treasuries Rebound By Bloomberg News
Treasury bonds and notes rebounded yesterday after stocks erased gains and fell, bolstering demand for fixed-income securities as safe-haven investments.
The 10-year Treasury note rose 3/32, to a price of 99 11/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.84 percent from 5.85 percent on Friday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 9/32, to 104 31/32. The bond's yield fell to 5.89 percent from 5.91 percent on Friday.

''Stocks are probably the most important'' focus for bonds, along with falling oil prices and then the euro, said Michael Cloherty, a strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston. Declines in stocks can ''help bonds slightly, but you'd have to see them really breaking lower to get much of a reaction,'' he said.
